sources.snippet: Agra Fort, another UNESCO world heritage monument, is an imposing red sandstone Mughal fort. Agra Fort is one of the finest Mughal forts in India and has an interesting history, it was constructed in 1565 by Emperor Akbar, initially as a military fort. Later, Shah Jahan (who built the Taj Mahal) transformed it into a palace before he was overthrown by his son Aurangzeb who imprisoned Shah Jahan in Agra Fort where he could only gaze out over the river to see the Taj Mahal glistening under the sunshine in the distance.
sources.shortName: My Agra Travel Guide: The Best Places to Visit, Eat & Stay

sources.snippet: The Taj Mahal isn't the only UNESCO World Heritage Site in Agra–the city is also home to Agra Fort, a centuries-old red sandstone fortress that was once the imperial city for a succession of Mughal rulers. Sightseeing here is like wandering around a city within a city. The most extraordinary building at Agra Fort is Jahangir Mahal, a massive palace that blends stunning Hindu-inspired features (like overhanging enclosed balconies) with Central Asian architectural elements (such as the signature pointed arches).
sources.shortName: 14 Top-Rated Attractions & Places to Visit in Agra

sources.snippet: Spread over a sprawling ninety four acres, this large crimson sandstone castle lies parallel to the Yamuna River and is situated 2 kilometres northwest of the Taj Mahal. The Agra castle changed into initially occupied by way of Sikarwar Rajputs and become later captured by means of Lodi rulers of Delhi. In 1526, after the Lodis had been defeated inside the struggle of Panipat, the victor Emperor Babur took over the fortress.
sources.shortName: Agra's Top Tourist Spots and Best Travel Destinations

sources.snippet: Many splendid palaces such as the Khas Palace and Jahangir Palace are located inside this medieval period building that is a legacy of its own. Diwan-e-Khas and few magnificent mosques are also located here. Built under Akbar’s rule in 1565, and situated on the banks of Yamuna river, this increases the magnificence of its complimenting Taj manifold.
sources.shortName: 10 Historic Places in Agra You Need to Visit, Must-See Places

sources.snippet: Agra Fort is one of the first-ever monuments in India to be declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983. It was constructed by the great Mughal emperor, Akbar in the 16th century. Initially, it used to be a Rajput fort called ‘Badalgarh’ which was rebuilt into the Agra Fort.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Agra, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: The Agra Fort, another outstanding structure from the Mughal empire, is on the list of UNESCO-designated sites in Agra. Situated along the Yamuna River’s banks not far from the Taj Mahal, this well-preserved red sandstone building is among the most amazing Agra attractions.
sources.shortName: Experience the India Golden Triangle Tour: Top 15 Places to Visit

sources.snippet: This UNESCO Word Heritage site is one of the most robust and important Mughal forts in India. After arriving in Agra in 1558, Emperor Akbar extensively rebuilt the fort using red sandstone. The process took eight years and was completed in 1573.
sources.shortName: 11 Places to Visit in Agra Beyond the Taj Mahal

sources.snippet: Also known as Lal Qila, Fort Rouge or Red Fort of Agra, the Agra Fort is a UNESCO world heritage site. It is situated at a distance of about 2.5 km northwest of the famous Taj Mahal.

Visitors can immerse themselves in the vibrant atmosphere of Old Delhi before strolling to Jama Masjid and Agra Fort. Exploring the bustling streets provides an authentic experience of this dynamic district. Additionally, travelers can take a taxi to visit the largest Hindu temple globally and continue their journey towards India Gate, concluding with a leisurely walk to the Presidential Palace.
placeMetadata.address: Rakabganj, Agra, Uttar Pradesh, India

placeMetadata.name: Taj Mahal

sources.snippet: The embodiment of all things pure”, said Rudyard Kipling on Taj Mahal’s beauty and that is no wordplay as the Taj is undoubtedly a pure epitome of beauty. It is an immortal poem in white marble and is the finest expression of love of an emperor for his queen. Located on a bank of River Yamuna, it was built by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his beloved wife and Queen Mumtaz Mahal in 1631, who died giving birth to his child and whose last wish to her husband was “to build such a tomb in her memory which the world has never seen before.” It took over 17 years, 22000 workers and 1000 elephants to build the wonderful mausoleum.

sources.snippet: Surely one in all Agra’s maximum popular sights, the Taj Mahal is not simply well-known in India but is a monument renowned across the world. Constructed via Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan for his deceased spouse Mumtaz, it's miles emblematic of the emperor’s deep love for his spouse and the grief he experienced at her passing. A landmark monument and a UNESCO international background website, the Taj Mahal is one of the most admired Mughal masterpieces within the global and is not anything short of poetry crafted in marble.
sources.shortName: Agra's Top Tourist Spots and Best Travel Destinations

sources.snippet: There isn’t any sight in India that is more famous than the Taj Mahal and you’d be crazy to travel India and not see the country’s most recognized monument and one of the Seven Wonders of the World. This famous monument to love and beautiful exercise in perfect symmetry really does live up to the hype as the most beautiful building in the world. The Taj has recently undergone restoration which is now finished making it a great time to visit to see the iconic landmark in all it’s beauty.

It is definitely one of the top 10 historic places in Agra you need to visit. Built by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan, as a shrine and cenotaph for his beloved wife Arjumand Bano Begum famously known as Mumtaz Mahal.

sources.snippet: There is no denying that the Taj Mahal, a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Agra, is one of the most recognizable buildings on the planet. Often referred to as “a teardrop on the cheek of eternity,” this taj mahal agra is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.

Built by Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal, it is described as an "elegy created in marble" and an "expression of true love." The monument's symmetrical gardens, minarets, and mosque add to its grandeur.

reviews.reviewText: "An architectural wonder that lives up to all the hype! The intricate details on the walls and the peaceful vibe around the monument are unforgettable. It’s a perfect spot for photography, especially at sunset. Highly recommend hiring a guide to learn the fascinating story of this iconic place. A true gem of India!"

It’s is a magnificent wonder of the world. The lore behind it is most intriguing, as well as the way it was built. For those who haven’t seen this wonder in person I would recommend doing so at least once.

However, beware of local people and children trying to obsessively sell things within the area. It gets a little annoying, but doesn’t take too much away from the wonderful experience.

Truly 1 of 7 wonders of the world. Need to see for yourself to believe it. Amazing architecture and excellent restoration by the government of India. Don't miss visiting it when you're in New Delhi. About 4 hours drive by tourist bus. The R&R is surprisingly very clean and neat.

Certainly worth your visit. There is a reason that it's amongst the wonders of the world. Beautiful Architecture and it's much beyond a marble building. Unbelievable that it was conceptualised like this centuries ago. Lots of applied science theories on display here & you may spend hours being mesmerised about it. The corridor and route is beautifully maintained and remains clean. Best time is Oct to Feb of the year since summers get a little too hard to bear

The TAJ MAHAL is a famous monument in India. It was built by the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in loving memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal. The Taj Mahal is made of white marble and has a beautiful garden. It has a big dome and four smaller domes.

Taj Mahal – A Timeless Wonder

Visiting the Taj Mahal was nothing short of magical. The moment you step through the gates and catch your first glimpse of the gleaming white marble, it feels like you've entered a dream. The symmetry, the intricate carvings, and the sheer scale of the monument are awe-inspiring.

I went early in the morning to avoid the crowds, and the soft light at sunrise made the whole place glow. It was absolutely worth it. The gardens are beautifully maintained, and the atmosphere is peaceful despite the number of visitors. Inside the mausoleum, the craftsmanship is delicate and respectful, though photography is restricted.

Tip: Wear comfortable shoes, bring water, and consider hiring a guide to truly appreciate the history and symbolism behind this masterpiece.

Whether you're a history buff, a romantic, or just someone who appreciates beauty, the Taj Mahal is a must-see. It’s not just a monument. It’s a feeling.

Now i agree why it is one of the wonders of the world.
Pure marble stones craved, designed and build stronger that lasts for centuries blew my mind a lot. Yes this monument blew my mind a lot.
And only tajmahal and agra fort is clean in this state i believe, i see most places must places still unhygienic, so i didn't took any risk fir visiting other places.

But i felt that 240 for a ticket is bit expensive

West entrance gate Heavy heavy crowded. But we entered via another gate directed by our guide, that is not popular. Take a good guide if its crowded, otherwise you have to wait half a day to enter. Don't take photographer who gives printed photo. Better to take mobile photographers who will give good photographs for 20 Rs. per photo.

placeMetadata.name: Mehtab Bagh

sources.snippet: A lawn constructed on the banks of Yamuna River, Mehtab Bagh became built via Emperor Babur and turned into the last of a series of 11 such gardens built alongside the east financial institution of the river. Mehtab Bagh was constructed as an vital a part of the Taj complicated because the gardens of the Taj are flawlessly aligned with Mehtab Bagh, making it the first-rate place to view the Taj from. Mehtab Bagh also joins two other gardens to the west called the Chahar Bagh Padshshi and 2nd Chahar Bagh Padshahi.
sources.shortName: Agra's Top Tourist Spots and Best Travel Destinations

sources.snippet: The Taj Mahal almost seems to extend across the Yamuna River at Mehtab Bagh (Moonlight Garden), a square garden complex measuring 300 meters on each side. It's the only remaining park in a series of nearly a dozen Mughal-built gardens in the area. The park has some pretty flowering trees and bushes–a stark improvement from its state in the mid-1990s, when the site was just a mound of sand.
sources.shortName: 14 Top-Rated Attractions & Places to Visit in Agra

sources.snippet: This 25 acre Mughal botanical garden complex on the opposite side of the river from the Taj Mahal offers good views of the monument, minus the crowds. The botanical gardens are open from sunrise to sunset and are perfectly aligned with the famous monument. It was the last garden built by the Mughal Empire and Shah Jahan himself saw it as an ideal place to view his beloved Taj Mahal.
sources.shortName: My Agra Travel Guide: The Best Places to Visit, Eat & Stay

sources.snippet: Mehtab Bagh in Agra stands at the North of the Taj Mahal and Agra Fort along the bank of river Yamuna. This is one of the many hidden places to visit in Agra. The garden is a char bagh which is a quadrilateral garden layout inspired by the four gardens of paradise mentioned in the Quran.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Agra, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: While planning a day of Taj Mahal sightseeing in Agra, don’t forget to visit the nearby Mehtab Bagh. This oasis-like garden complex, located across the Yamuna River, dates back to the 16th century and offers another beautiful perspective on the Taj Mahal.
sources.shortName: Experience the India Golden Triangle Tour: Top 15 Places to Visit

sources.snippet: You will get some of the best views of Taj Mahal from the Mehtab Bagh. It is a four-garden complex and is the ultimate viewing point of the magnificent Taj Mahal. The garden which is open from sunrise to sunset and is a photographer’s heaven.

reviews.reviewText: This is Mehtab Bagh .. you can see Very nice and stunning views of taj mahal from here. Separate entry tickets for point view and garden .. please take change with you or else use phone pe.. Luggage was not allowed inside you have to leave in vehicles please keep the place clean. Spend as much time as u can and see the beauty of taj mahal and also the garden.

Our evening at Mehtab Bagh with friends was the absolute highlight of our Agra visit—a perfectly serene and breathtaking alternative to the crowds at the Taj Mahal. Located directly across the Yamuna River, this charbagh (Mughal garden) offers the most stunning and uninterrupted panoramic view of the Taj Mahal, especially as the sun begins to set and the white marble glows in the golden light. It was the ideal spot for our group to relax, take incredible photos, and simply soak in the majestic beauty of one of the world’s wonders in a peaceful, unhurried atmosphere. The gardens themselves are well-maintained and spacious, giving us plenty of room to stroll, sit on the lawns, and enjoy the reflective ambiance away from the noise. Whether you're a photography enthusiast, a history lover, or just looking for a memorable place to unwind with friends, Mehtab Bagh delivers a magical and almost surreal experience. It’s the perfect way to end a day in Agra—calm, beautiful, and utterly unforgettable. Highly recommended for anyone wanting to see the Taj Mahal from a unique and picture-perfect perspective!

A hidden gem with historical significance, this place offers a breathtaking view of Taj Mahal. Visit during sunset for a better experience (most probably it remains open from sunrise to sunset), food is not allowed inside

Beautiful view of the Taj Mahal. The ticket for the park is sufficient. The extra cost for the photo opportunity isn't worth it. There's no time limit on the visit. You can spend a wonderful time here with family or friends. Please take your trash home so this park stays beautiful for a long time.
Mehtab Bagh is one of the biggest garden. There is an entry ticket 25 INR and taj view point has different entrance with 35 INR ticket.

It's a very nice place...

There is nothing much to do here, walk with your family and kinds, take photos and have a separate view point  for taj mahal with extra tickets but I don't think it is required. sources.snippet: Situated contrary the Agra fort is the grand Jama Masjid, Agra’s most essential and biggest mosque. Commissioned via Shah Jahan in 1648, the mosque topped with purple sandstone domes, is thought for its stunning structure. 5 massive arches result in the primary prayer corridor inside the Jama Masjid, that are skimmed with the aid of a lovely bolster of sandstone embellished with floral motifs.
sources.shortName: Agra's Top Tourist Spots and Best Travel Destinations

sources.snippet: One of India's largest mosques can be found in the historic core of Agra, just across from the Agra Fort. Still the city's principal mosque, the Jama Masjid was built during the 17th century under the reign of Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan. The striking red sandstone structure stands atop a platform, and features remarkable white marble inlay with blue-washed ceilings and walls.
sources.shortName: 14 Top-Rated Attractions & Places to Visit in Agra

sources.snippet: Originally named the Jami Masjid, Jama Masjid was built by Shah Jahan. The best artisans, engineers, sculptors, and laborers were involved in making of this grand mosque, one of the biggest in the world. Its size can be estimated from the fact that it can accommodate more than 25,000 people at any given point.
sources.shortName: 10 Historic Places in Agra You Need to Visit, Must-See Places

sources.snippet: The Jama Masjid mosque, one of the biggest in all of India, is the main attraction within the Fatehpur Sikri complex near Agra. Still in use today, it is one of the best Mughal structures in the nation and, in the words of UNESCO, “one of India’s most exquisite architectural achievements.

sources.snippet: The Jama Masjid is one of the most beautiful mosques in India. Built on lines similar to the one in Delhi, this mosque too is an architectural splendour. The construction of this mosque was started in 1839 by Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah Bahadur.

sources.snippet: Jama Masjid in Agra is opposite to the Agra Fort and overlooking the Agra Fort Railway Station. The Jama Masjid is also popularly known as the Jami Masjid or "Friday Mosque".

reviews.reviewText:
Great Place. Only Rs.50/- ticket and worth visiting.

Take a guide if possible since no detail is written inside near the monuments

Guides will start from around Rs.2000/- charge but you may easily negotiate for Rs. 500/-

If you are a good negotiator and depending on the season, you may get it for even Rs.200/-

Agra Fort, also known as Agra's Red Fort, is a historic Mughal fort in Agra, India. Built in 1565 by Akbar as a military structure, it was later transformed into a palace by Shah Jahan. This 94-acre fort is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, featuring impressive imperial quarters, mosques, and gardens. Notable structures include the Jahangiri Mahal, Khas Mahal, and Mussaman Burj, where Shah Jahan was imprisoned by Aurangzeb. The fort showcases Mughal architecture, blending Islamic and Hindu styles. It's open daily from 6 am to 6 pm, with an entrance fee of Rs 50 for Indians and Rs 600 for foreigners

Amazing Architecture. Grandeur visited!! Only thing is.. we forgot our water bottle..  there is no drinking water facility available inside. It's only near the gate which is far off and the fort area is huge..

It was a friends short trip so we had fun visiting fort. First time visitors should get a guide although make them lower their prices. The cloaking room is free.
If you want quiet and quality time then i suggest go on week days.

Few of the parts of fort are really smelly. Although the scenes are good from fort top. It's near by taj mahal too.

Outside you can find stalls and accessories in cheap prices.

You definitely need a guide to show you around as there's limited signage but the background is fascinating. There also an optical illusion from a certain room viewing the Taj that's quite trippy. The site is pretty huge so you could spend well over an hour here. Buy your tickets online.

Agra Fort is not just a monument, it’s a walk through time. The moment I entered, I could feel the powerful energy of the Mughal Empire still alive in its massive red sandstone walls. The fort is huge and beautifully maintained, with grand gateways and a perfect mix of strong defense structures and royal elegance.

This fort is far far better than red fort situated in delhi. Jamunaji is following from just near by which can be seen from the fort clearly which makes it more beautiful. It's really clean and well maintained. All the places are open to visit for tourists unlike red fort of new delhi.
Cheap to visit and worth a visit. Not too steep to get to the top. It is a historic fort still used by the army 75% of it. Well worth a visit

placeMetadata.name: Anguri Bagh

sources.snippet: Centrally situated in the premises of Khas Mahal, Anguri Bagh was built by using Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in 1637. Because the call shows, Khas Mahal (or Aramgah- i - Muqaddasa) became built for the emperor as his exalted area of amusement and rest, to suit his taste. Besides the several different additions within the palace, the primary element includes a corridor with recess and rooms in a surrounding semicircular pattern and a large courtyard within the the front with tanks, fountains and hammams overlooking a wonderful garden that is- Anguri Bagh.

placeMetadata.address: 52HF+966, Agra Fort, Rakabganj, Agra, Uttar Pradesh 282003, India

reviews.reviewText:
Anguri Bagh – The Royal Mughal Garden!

📍 Location: Inside Agra Fort, Uttar Pradesh

🌿 Significance: Built by Emperor Shah Jahan in 1637 as a private retreat, famous for its lush greenery and symmetrical design.

🎭 Architecture: A charbagh-style garden with intricate pathways, water channels, and fountains, once filled with grapevines and fragrant flowers.

🏰 Royal Connection: Part of Khas Mahal, where Mughal queens and princesses relaxed amidst nature.

🎟 Entry Fees: Included in the Agra Fort ticket.

🔎 How to Reach? Inside Agra Fort, just 2.5 km from the Taj Mahal and 1.5 km from Agra Cantt Railway Station.

A serene escape within the fort, offering a glimpse into the luxurious Mughal lifestyle!

“The Mughal Secret Garden You Didn’t Know You Needed”

Tucked quietly inside Agra Fort, Anguri Bagh is where symmetry meets serenity.

Once a royal retreat for Mughal queens, this garden isn't just about grapes (yes, “Anguri” means grapes) — it’s about grace. The geometric flower beds, the marble fountains, and that breathtaking view of the white pavilions around it... you’ll forget the chaos outside.

Stand at the center, close your eyes — you can almost hear the veiled laughter of the royal zenana and the splash of fountains long silenced by time.

Perfect spot for: ✅ Jaw-dropping photos
✅ That calm, meditative moment
✅ Imagining you’re in a Mughal fairytale

📍Tip: Visit early morning for the best light and the least crowd.

This isn’t just a garden. It’s poetry in marble and grass.

#AnguriBagh #HiddenGemOfAgra #MughalRetreat #ZenanaVibes #AgraFortDiaries

Located just opposite to the Deewan-I-Aam of Shah Jahan, Anguri bagh was known for rich harvesting of grapes and flowers. You will be able to see amazing symmetry structure. There is a fountain in the middle. This garden was preserved for relaxation of royal ladies.

Anguri baug is inside Agra fort so visit the whole fort and take time within baug it's worth visiting. Architecture of the building is brilliant you would see things in a straight line even at distant and aligning the whole bagug

Anguri Bagh comes under Agra fort monument.  It's build by Akbar in 1573. If you're planning to visit for best viewing experience visit it in early morning or early evening time. Purchase tickets online to avoid crowds and get discounts. Parking available but at certain cost bus stand and railway station is nearby by around 1 km away from main get. Calm and peaceful place. Suggest time in year is spring and winter season. Drinking water available but carry your own bottle. Clean washroom available. Staff are helping and supporting. All the monuments are not open to visit all time so please insure if you are looking for some special architecture.

Beautiful 😍 Anguri or Grape garden built in Mughal style. Maintained very well as a part of Agra fort tourist 👏 attraction. There are fountains ⛲️ also located in it but they were not working when we visited. Agra fort ticket is 50 rs for Indians and 650 rs for foreigners. It takes 10 rs via metro to reach here from Taj mahal 👌.

This was basically a grape garden surrounded by the residences of the royal ladies (Zenana) and was believed to produce the choicest grapes.
It was constructed in the normal Mughal Char Bagh type garden structure with elevated pathways.
There is a fountain in the centre of the criss-cross pathways. Unfortunately it is no longer functioning.
It is still a beautiful place, through the grapes have long been forgotten!
Very well-preserved.

The garden was originally built by the Mughal emperor Akbar in the 16th century and was later renovated by his grandson, Shah Jahan.
The garden is named Anguri Bagh, which means "grape garden," because it was originally planted with grapevines. The garden is surrounded by a high wall and features a central water channel with fountains. The water channel is lined with beautiful flower beds and trees.
The garden was used by the Mughal emperors as a place of relaxation and retreat. It is said that Shah Jahan would often come here to enjoy the beauty of the garden and spend time with his family.

placeMetadata.name: Musamman Burj

sources.snippet: This has a special significance in Mughal history as being the Octagonal tower built by Shah Jahan as a palace for Mumtaz Mahal in the year 1631–40. This is also the place where his son Aurangzeb imprisoned him along with his younger daughter Jahanara Begum until his death. A multi-storied tower inlaid with precious gemstones, the citadel provides an excellent view of Agra City.
sources.shortName: 10 Historic Places in Agra You Need to Visit, Must-See Places

placeMetadata.description: Octagonal marble Mughal tower with precious gems & stone lattices, with views of the Taj Mahal.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Musamman Burj is an octagonal marble tower located within the complex of the Taj Mahal in Agra, India. It features intricate stone lattices and precious gems, offering stunning views of the iconic Taj Mahal. The tower was once the residence of two prominent queens, Nur Jahan and Mumtaz Mahal. Additionally, it is known for its exquisite stone inlay work.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Agra Art Gallery showcases a collection of handcrafted masterpieces that reflect the artistic skills and creativity passed down through generations of artisans involved in the construction and design of the Taj Mahal. The products are intricately designed, drawing inspiration from the iconic monument. The gallery prioritizes customer service, ensuring that visitors receive high-quality, genuine goods. Guests have praised the variety and quality of art pieces on display, as well as the exceptional hospitality provided by owner Mr. Veerendra Singh and his staff.
placeMetadata.address: 30-B, Munro Road, Sadar Bazar, Shahzadi Mandi, Idgah Colony, Agra, Uttar Pradesh 282001, India

reviews.reviewText: Rahul at Agra Art Gallery is a kind and honest man who genuinely loves his trade. His clear explanation of the beautiful artworks was very interesting. I’m so happy with my purchases. Will definitely return again.

The teaching session was very informative, short enough but clear. Marble products are great and the craftsmanship is something to appreciate. Only marked it 4-star due to the persistent selling from staff when I am just trying to gather my thoughts and said so.

Must visit places if you are looking for authentic Pietra Dura craft items. You could find some cheaper souvenirs but a lot of them are a bit on the expensive side. Definitely worth it if you like collectibles. The tables, glasses, and antique items are exquisite and worthy of a connoisseur. I purchased a small and beautiful ring box here and got a good discount since we were buying more items for friends. The proprietor doesn't allow items to be photographed. Nevertheless, you may be intrigued by the craft station here where the artists do all the Pietra Dura works and see for yourself how it's done. Many Taj Mahal inspired motifs and designs are their speciality. I was dazzled to see the Pietra Dura replica of the famous painting- The Last Supper.  Overall, a place to visit if you are interested in stone art.

Spent 4 months at this gallery learning the work of marble inlay. It has been life changing, such a great gallery and even greater family. Highly recommend anyone who visits the Taj Mahal to visit this place! The work is unreal

This place is keeping the historical artistry alive - having an artist who’s a descendant of the people who built the Taj Mahal!

Phenomenal explanations of the intricate work that goes into carefully crafting the pieces

Very hospitable staff - definitely worth a visit !!!

Beautiful gallery, the descendant of the Taj Mahal builders and artists, one of the last generations to continue this artistry. Beautiful products, jewelers and piece of Indian history. A must visit in Agra!
Prices are extremely high . You can buy exactly the same items at the souvenirsshops at the airport . Only in agra art gallery they are 4 to 5 times more expensive.
They will tell you any lie to sell their art for over the top prices. Buy here and you will regret it

placeMetadata.name: Jodha Bai ka Rauza

sources.snippet: This palace was made by Akbar for her, suiting her simple, sophisticated yet elegant life. The palace was made in Rajasthani and Gujarati architectural styles with some inputs from Mughal designs. Located in Fatehpur Sikri, Taj Mahal can still be seen from the slit openings in the walls of the palace.
sources.shortName: 10 Historic Places in Agra You Need to Visit, Must-See Places

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Jodha Bai ka Rauza, situated in Fatehpur Sikri, was constructed for Akbar's beloved wife. This palace is adjacent to the Jahangiri Mahal and features a unique architectural style that combines elements of Rajasthani, Gujarati, and possibly Hindu art. The design includes small openings in the walls that offer views of the Taj Mahal. It reflects Akbar's appreciation for diverse architectural influences and exquisite designs.

The tour company's owner, Ali, was in touch with me the day before each tour to provide all the information I needed, including what I needed to bring for a seamless trip, and answered any questions that I had. My tour of Delhi, Agra and Jaipur was a great success and I thoroughly enjoyed every minute of it.All of the drivers were very kind and drove carefully on the highways, which I appreciated, and even stopped for me to get some energizing chai along the way. We have booked a 4-day tour from Agra to Jaipur with Aiza Tours and couldn’t have been happier. While reaching out to the operator Mr Ali, we shared our preferences of what to see, but let him guide to consolidate and propose an order. Everything was very smooth and well organized.
We were picked-up by the guide and driver at the airport, and taken care until drop-off at the airport again a few days later. We felt very comfortable at any time, and whenever we had questions or concerns either Mr. Ali or the guides in Agra and Jaipur took care of us.
Our tour started in Agra at airport, picked up by the guide Mr Hyder Ali and Mr Jeedu and brought to the hotel. From there, we then visited Agra Fort and the Baby Taj, receiving great insights and background. The next morning, we got to see the beautiful Taj Mahal, again very well guided. After breakfast back in the hotel, we were driven to Jaipur, while stopping on the way at Fatehpur Sikri and at a (tourist) restaurant for lunch. Our driver Mr. Jeedu was very professional and a careful driver, we felt always comfortable.
In Jaipur, we started the next day with a visit at the Amber Fort, followed by the Jal Mahal, Hawa Mahal, Jantar Mantar and City palace. It was a very interesting tour with good inputs. The last day, we then went to the Nahargarh Fort and Jai Garh fort, followed by another stop at the hotel, before then being dropped off at the airport.

The whole tour was very well organized and I would highly recommend to book with Mr Ali, as he is highly responsive and takes great care of the guests, and reflects all asks and concerns.

sources.snippet: To experience what Agra felt like many years ago, Kinari Bazar a must- visit. Located behind Jama Masjid in the narrow streets, you will find a multitude of colourful little shops here. This is the place for some of the finest jewellery in Agra, as well as shoes, clothing, authentic snack stalls, and Agra’s famous marble-work.

reviews.reviewText: This place is known for whole sale market for stuffs like clothing, eatables, jewellery, household items, medicines and some other objects. It is recommended to go on foot rather than two wheeler or four wheeler because this place is too much congested and too much crowded. You can find best things at very affordable prices.

Its a very old and famous market of agra for wholesale and retail purpose for jewellery, utensils, Cosmetic, and other stuff.

Very crowded and try to come here by foot
Taking your car or bike will result in a large traffic jam Because the roads and full of people and narrow
Near Lal quila or bijli ghar . Place is very useful for jewellery shopping and bride groom products shopping . Very reasonable price
Avoid kinari bazar if possible between 12 in the noon to 9pm.

The famous market of the Agra, well known for clothes and jewellery. The streets inside market are quite narrow and the market place remain always crowded. But the market is quite important and here you can get almost each and everything at reasonable prices.
P.S. be ready to negotiate the prices as much as you can.

I liked this market very much as it is hub for purchasing multiple items at one place. Good shops with latest products and prices are too reasonable.
Shopping clothing accessories jewelry....Utensils electronics items....Chat parodies Bhalla chat etc are also available in market in shops and theli too.
Overall good place situated in the heart of the city. Chat Bhalla preparation one can try without failure. Gold jewelry can also purchased on very reasonable prices. Sunday outing and shopping road sides is recommended.

Conjusted area. Better to go with public transport. But good place for shopping. It's a wholesale market for retailers and one can also buy at retailers price.. Well known market in Agra. Buy jewellery, clothes, makeup and all household items.

I went there for a walk as it was suggested online, but was not a touristy place at all. Not a good place neither for walk/visit, nor for shopping. Nothing similar to a "bazaar"! Do not waste your time here.

We recently did a Private Golden Triangle Tour with family, and it was an amazing experience from start to finish. The tour was well-organized, with a comfortable car, punctual pickups, and knowledgeable local guides in each city. We explored Delhi’s historic sites, marveled at the Taj Mahal in Agra, and enjoyed the royal vibe of Jaipur’s palaces and forts. The itinerary was well-paced, giving us enough time to relax and explore. Our driver was courteous and ensured our safety throughout. Traveling as a family, we felt secure and taken care of. This trip gave us memories to cherish forever. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a hassle-free, enriching cultural journey in India’s most iconic destinations.

Our tour guides anil and satish were very knowledgeable.
The tour organizer gopal manage every thing very well and always ready to help us .
Highly recommended!

Best Travel Plan!

I had  a wonderful trip to the Golden Triangle cities—Delhi, Agra, and Jaipur—and also visited the beautiful city of Udaipur. Each place had its own charm and cultural richness. In Delhi, I explored historic sites and lively streets, while Agra left me awestruck with the stunning Taj Mahal. Jaipur was full of colors, heritage palaces, and vibrant markets where our driver even helped us bargain for some great souvenirs. Udaipur, with its calm lakes and royal architecture, was the most peaceful and picturesque part of the journey. We stayed in luxurious hotels that made the experience even more special. The food, the people, and the atmosphere in every city added to the joy. It was a memorable journey filled with culture, comfort, and unforgettable moments.

It was a really amazing experience with Delhi Jaipur Agra Tour. We have booked Rajasthan tour for our official get together. We booked this trip from Austria for our 15 team members. The over all experience was great. Price were very nominal and we really like the service. Cheers !!

Best Private Tour!

The Golden Triangle with Rajasthan tour was an unforgettable experience. The entire trip was perfectly planned, covering Delhi, Agra, Jaipur, and the stunning cities of Rajasthan like Udaipur and Jodhpur. From the majestic Taj Mahal to the royal forts and palaces, every destination was rich in history and culture. The itinerary was balanced, giving us enough time to explore without feeling rushed. Comfortable accommodations, smooth transportation, and knowledgeable guides made the journey enjoyable and stress-free. The desert experience in Jaisalmer and the boat ride in Udaipur added a magical touch. Every detail was thoughtfully arranged, making the tour seamless and memorable. I highly recommend this tour for anyone looking to explore the best of North India with a royal twist.

A Cultural Trip!

Our 4-day Golden Triangle trip was an unforgettable blend of history, culture, and vibrant flavors. We began in Delhi, exploring majestic landmarks like Qutub Minar and India Gate, immersed in their rich past. Jaipur welcomed us with its royal charm—Amber Fort and City Palace stood as testaments to Rajasthan’s grandeur. The authentic Rajasthani cuisine was a delight, with every bite reflecting tradition and spice. Capturing the beauty of these forts through our lens was a highlight. Agra’s Taj Mahal, ethereal at sunrise, left us spellbound. A special mention to our guide, Ramesh, whose deep knowledge and engaging storytelling added immense value to the experience. His insights brought each monument to life. This journey was truly enriching and beautifully woven with history, heritage, and heartfelt hospitality.

Highly Recommended !

Our Delhi-Jaipur-Agra trip with a detour to Varanasi was unforgettable. Starting in Delhi, we explored historical sites like India Gate and Qutub Minar. Jaipur charmed us with its vibrant culture, Amber Fort, and street food. Agra’s Taj Mahal was breathtaking—more stunning than pictures. But the soul of our journey was Varanasi. The Ganga Aarti at Dashashwamedh Ghat left us speechless; the spiritual vibe was overwhelming. Boating at sunrise and wandering the narrow ghats created lifelong memories. Traveling with friends made every moment joyful—late-night chats, roadside chai, and endless laughter. Despite the heat and hectic travel, the bond we shared and the cultural richness we witnessed made it a perfect blend of fun, history, and spirituality.

Glad to have him as our guide as he described every event beautifully.

Overall very satisfying to know Mugal life the palaces. However, suggested to go in 1st half to have ample time to see. The monument is very good. All restaurants in the route get closed in evening around 6pm. Please enquire about Chaadar offering amount at Sikri Dargah as guide might not tell you. It's upto you. Also, souvenirs are costly.
Very good experience. Guide was very polite and have good knowledge about monument.

Stay away from this person. He will be friendly at the beginning and explain basic things about the place. Later he will ask you for a 5 Star google review. And then he will start showing his true color.
He took us to all his friends stores and forced us to purchase expensive items from that store. As if he is the sales person of that store. Initially we ignored that as most of the tour guides do the same. But this man kept on taking us one shop after another even after clarifying that we are not interested. Then one point he started imotional blackmailing too. It became so irritating that we thought of ending the tour prematurely.
I have been to many places in the last few years but never met such a horrible guide.

ops.insert: The historic red sandstone fort dates back to the Mughal Dynasty & holds palaces & mosques.
17th-century, Mughal-style, marble mausoleum with minarets, a mosque & famously symmetrical gardens.
Partly ruined formal Mughal-era gardens restored in the 1990s, with famous Taj Mahal views.
Richly decorated semi-circular red sandstone fort complex with double ramparts & monuments.
Sprawling historical courtyard in front of the Khas Mahal, with a formal charbagh-style garden.

data.title: The 33 best photo spots in Agra

placeMetadata.name: Taj Mahal

sources.snippet: About Agra: Agra’s greatest claim to fame is as the site of the Taj Mahal , mausoleum of the Indian Mughal empress Mumtaz Mahal, and built by her husband the emperor in her memory. A staggering sight notwithstanding its status as almost a stock image, the poignancy of the white marble architectural masterpiece led poet Rabindranath Tagore to describe the Taj as “a teardrop on the cheek of eternity.” While the rest of the city can feel a bit crowded with souvenir vendors and tour guides longing to help you preserve your memories of the Taj, the Agra Fort , a well preserved red brick structure built by Emperor Akbar, and Mughal gardens await the traveler ready to look a bit deeper. Likewise, an overnight or two will afford the chance to contemplate the Yamuna river while sampling local petha candy or savory snacks called chaat.
sources.shortName: Agra Pictures - Agra Travel Photos

sources.snippet: The world believes Taj Mahal was built by love but understanding Shah Jahan’s chronicles on the Taj, one could conclude it was grief that built the architectural marvel and it was sorrow that saw it through thirty five years of his life since the demise of his beloved wife. The third wife of Emperor Shah Jahan, Mumtaz was his dearest and their love story is legendary. It is widely believed that she was a devoted consort and content to have more offspring with her husband – tragically she died giving birth to their 14th child.
sources.shortName: 6 Useful Tips For Photographing The Taj Mahal Agra

sources.snippet: Home to the world-renowned Taj Mahal, Agra offers a dreamlike setting for couples embarking on their journey into marital bliss. Located on the banks of river Yamuna, the city of love houses the best architectural gems of the Mughal era. Today, we're embarking on a journey through the city's heart, unveiling the most mesmerizing pre-wedding shoot locations in Agra that promise to immortalize your love story against the tapestry of architectural marvels and serene gardens.
sources.shortName: 13 Pre-Wedding Shoot Locations In Agra You Need To Save!

sources.snippet: When I first learnt about the Taj Mahal, I learnt of the great love story – it was built in memory of Mumtaz Mahal, the wife of Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan. He wanted to show his undying love for her in the world’s greatest, most impressive monument. I was told it used to be even more impressive than it is now, with at least 28 gemstones and precious metals laid into the intricate carvings of the walls, but over time thieves stole gems straight out of the walls.
sources.shortName: The Taj Mahal Photography Guide and Best spots

sources.snippet: At a distance of 6 km from Agra Cantonment Railway Station, Taj Mahal, one of the most popular tourist destinations in the world, is located on the southern bank of the Yamuna River in Agra of Uttar Pradesh State. Taj Mahal was declared as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1983 and it is also counted among the seven wonders of the modern world. It attracts around four million visitors annually.
sources.shortName: 26 Best Places to Visit in Agra, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: Without doubt one of Agra's main attractions is the Taj Mahal which symbolizes both architectural perfection and love for eternity. It allows one to watch as its marble face undergoes several changes as each moment captures your attention differently. The reflective pools and beautiful gardens enclosing this mausoleum will provide enough scenes that depict postcard images.
sources.shortName: Discover The Top 10 Photography Spots In Historic Agra For Stunning Shots

sources.snippet: You’ve paid the entry fee, walked around the complex of Taj Mahal, marvelled at the intricate carvings on walls, and it’s time to leave. But you don’t have a single photo that does justice to the sheer scale of the Taj Mahal. Fret not – just head to either of the two red mosques (preferably the one on the  that flank the main ivory building inside the Taj Mahal complex.
sources.shortName: 5 BEST ways of photographing the Taj Mahal, Agra

sources.snippet: Taj Mahal, one of the new 7 wonders of the World was high on my bucket list for years. Being an Indian, I always felt so embarrassed that I hadn’t seen this wonder ever (I am not accounting the visit when I was 6 months old, which I obviously don’t remember!). So ever since I moved from USA to Singapore, this visit was topmost in my priority list.
sources.shortName: Taj Mahal – Best Travel & Photography Guide

sources.snippet: The most popular place in Agra to get a photo of yourself is straight in front of the Taj Mahal. There’s a small pool in front of you and a long pool stretching off behind you. Both provide beautiful mirror-like reflections and with the iconic white marble tomb behind you, this shot is a classic for a reason.
sources.shortName: 13 Instagram-Worthy Spots in Agra with Examples

sources.snippet: The Taj Mahal is accounted for as the epitome of love and beauty. It is one of the seven wonders of the world and is an example of fine mughalian craftsmanship. Built under the aegis of Shah Jahan for his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal the Taj Mahal is one of the best  prewedding shoot locations in Agra.
sources.shortName: #15 Beautiful Prewedding Shoot Locations In Agra To Spruce Up Your Romance

sources.snippet: The tour starts with a visit to Taj Mahal, a modern Wonder of the World. Apart from learning about History, our guide will show you spots from where you can capture beautiful architecture. Then you visit Red Fort, another Iconic building that offers a breathtaking backdrop for your pictures.
sources.shortName: Full-Day Private Tour of the Best Photography Spots in Agra in Agra, Uttar Pradesh

sources.snippet: The ‘Symbol of Love’ Taj Mahal is on the topmost position of every list containing places to visit in Agra. Crafted with perfection, it took almost 21 years and over 20,000 laborers working day and night. Catching a sight of this architectural marvel is the best thing to do in Agra.
sources.shortName: 21 Top Things to do in Agra in 2020 with Reviews, Photos & Price

sources.snippet: You've seen it in history books, on postcards, and in social media posts. But now, you've made your way to India, and you finally have the chance to see this bucket list destination in real life. The magnificent structure dates back to the 17th century.
sources.shortName: 14 Top-Rated Attractions & Places to Visit in Agra

sources.snippet: No visit to Agra is complete without seeing the Taj Mahal, one of the Seven Wonders of the World. Built-in honour of his wife, Mumtaz Mahal, Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan’s ivory-white marble tomb is well-known for its exquisite symmetry and construction.
sources.shortName: Capture the Essence of India's Heritage

sources.snippet: Sikandra is located in Agra about 15 kilometers from the Taj Mahal.From New Delhi Airport, it will be around 240 km via the Taj Express Highway and will take 4 hours by Taxi. It is a common destination for all who visit the great Taj Mahal.
sources.shortName: Sikandra - Best Photo Spots

sources.snippet: One of the seven wonders of the world, the Taj Mahal stands tall at the south bank of the river Yamuna in Agra. Taj Mahal or the “icon of love” is one of the best places to visit in Agra and the most popular tourist destinations in India.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Agra, Tourist Places & Top Attractions
7 AMAZING Taj Mahal View Point Locations in Agra

sources.snippet: The charm of Taj Mahal attracts people from all over the world. It is one of the most beautiful heritage destinations of India. Being one of the seven wonders of the world, this white marble structure resembles paradise on earth.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Tourist Places to Visit in Agra | Agra Tour

sources.snippet: Agra is home to the Majestic Taj Mahal but there is so much more to offer, so even if you are tight for time in Agra this is a great itinerary for the best places to visit in Agra in one day.
sources.shortName: 9 Best Tourist Places To Visit In Agra In One Day

sources.snippet: The tour starts with a visit to Taj Mahal, a modern Wonder of the World. Apart from learning about History, our guide will show you spots from where you can capture beautiful architecture.

sources.snippet: Situated on the banks of Yamuna, the Taj Mahal in Agra is a monumental ode to eternal love. This 17th-century mausoleum was built for Mumtaz Mahal by her husband and Mughal Empe...
sources.shortName: Best Places to visit in Agra: Entry Fee, Timings, Location

sources.snippet: Capturing the essence of iconic landmarks like the Taj Mahal and Agra Red Fort, this full-day private tour promises a blend of photography and culture.
sources.shortName: Full-Day Private Tour Of The Best Photography Spots In Agra
12 Best Taj Mahal Viewpoints in Agra, India

placeMetadata.description: 17th-century, Mughal-style, marble mausoleum with minarets, a mosque & famously symmetrical gardens.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Taj Mahal, a 17th-century Mughal-style marble mausoleum located in Agra, India, is a breathtaking symbol of love and architectural mastery. Built by Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal, it is described as an "elegy created in marble" and an "expression of true love." The monument's symmetrical gardens, minarets, and mosque add to its grandeur.
placeMetadata.address: Dharmapuri, Forest Colony, Tajganj, Agra, Uttar Pradesh 282001, India

reviews.reviewText: "An architectural wonder that lives up to all the hype! The intricate details on the walls and the peaceful vibe around the monument are unforgettable. It’s a perfect spot for photography, especially at sunset. Highly recommend hiring a guide to learn the fascinating story of this iconic place. A true gem of India!"

It’s is a magnificent wonder of the world. The lore behind it is most intriguing, as well as the way it was built. For those who haven’t seen this wonder in person I would recommend doing so at least once.

However, beware of local people and children trying to obsessively sell things within the area. It gets a little annoying, but doesn’t take too much away from the wonderful experience.

Truly 1 of 7 wonders of the world. Need to see for yourself to believe it. Amazing architecture and excellent restoration by the government of India. Don't miss visiting it when you're in New Delhi. About 4 hours drive by tourist bus. The R&R is surprisingly very clean and neat.

Certainly worth your visit. There is a reason that it's amongst the wonders of the world. Beautiful Architecture and it's much beyond a marble building. Unbelievable that it was conceptualised like this centuries ago. Lots of applied science theories on display here & you may spend hours being mesmerised about it. The corridor and route is beautifully maintained and remains clean. Best time is Oct to Feb of the year since summers get a little too hard to bear

The TAJ MAHAL is a famous monument in India. It was built by the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in loving memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal. The Taj Mahal is made of white marble and has a beautiful garden. It has a big dome and four smaller domes.

Taj Mahal – A Timeless Wonder

Visiting the Taj Mahal was nothing short of magical. The moment you step through the gates and catch your first glimpse of the gleaming white marble, it feels like you've entered a dream. The symmetry, the intricate carvings, and the sheer scale of the monument are awe-inspiring.

I went early in the morning to avoid the crowds, and the soft light at sunrise made the whole place glow. It was absolutely worth it. The gardens are beautifully maintained, and the atmosphere is peaceful despite the number of visitors. Inside the mausoleum, the craftsmanship is delicate and respectful, though photography is restricted.

Tip: Wear comfortable shoes, bring water, and consider hiring a guide to truly appreciate the history and symbolism behind this masterpiece.

Whether you're a history buff, a romantic, or just someone who appreciates beauty, the Taj Mahal is a must-see. It’s not just a monument. It’s a feeling.

Now i agree why it is one of the wonders of the world.
Pure marble stones craved, designed and build stronger that lasts for centuries blew my mind a lot. Yes this monument blew my mind a lot.
And only tajmahal and agra fort is clean in this state i believe, i see most places must places still unhygienic, so i didn't took any risk fir visiting other places.

But i felt that 240 for a ticket is bit expensive

West entrance gate Heavy heavy crowded. But we entered via another gate directed by our guide, that is not popular. Take a good guide if its crowded, otherwise you have to wait half a day to enter. Don't take photographer who gives printed photo. Better to take mobile photographers who will give good photographs for 20 Rs. per photo.

placeMetadata.name: Mehtab Bagh

sources.snippet: At a distance of 9.5 km from Agra Cantonment Railway Station, Mehtab Bagh is a charbagh complex situated north of the Taj Mahal complex and the Agra Fort on the other side of Yamuna River.The Mehtab Bagh garden was the last of eleven Mughal-built gardens along the Yamuna River; the first being Ram Bagh. The emperor Shah Jahan noted this crescent-shaped flood plain covered with grass around the Yamuna River and found it a great location to view the Taj Mahal from some distance. He then conceptualized it as a pleasure garden filled with moonlight and name it Mehtab Bagh during 1631 to 1635.Mehtab Bagh is a 25 acre garden, square in shape, measures about 300 x 300 m and is perfectly aligned with the Taj Mahal on the opposite bank.
sources.shortName: 26 Best Places to Visit in Agra, Things to Do & Sightseeing (2024)

sources.snippet: We have specifically included Mehtab Bagh in the end as to give travelers another glimpse of Taj at the time of sunset. The view of The Taj Mahal from here is surreal, where you can white Taj in saffron lit twilight sky, and the magnificent reflection of Taj in the Yamuna river. Considered to be the site for the Black Taj Mahal, whose construction never saw the light of the day due to rift in the Royal Family, later it was converted to the gardens, this is the last garden of the Mughal era in Agra.
sources.shortName: Full-Day Private Tour of the Best Photography Spots in Agra in Agra

sources.snippet: Situated across the Yamuna River, Mehtab Bagh offers the Taj Mahal's splendour from a different perspective. The lush greenery, tranquil water bodies and unobstructed view of the Taj Mahal at sunset make it a romantic haven for capturing intimate moments against the changing hues of the sky. If you're looking to escape the crowds, then visit this pre-wedding shoot location in Agra during the early morning hours.
sources.shortName: 13 Pre-Wedding Shoot Locations In Agra You Need To Save!

sources.snippet: The Taj Mahal almost seems to extend across the Yamuna River at Mehtab Bagh (Moonlight Garden), a square garden complex measuring 300 meters on each side. It's the only remaining park in a series of nearly a dozen Mughal-built gardens in the area. The park has some pretty flowering trees and bushes–a stark improvement from its state in the mid-1990s, when the site was just a mound of sand.
sources.shortName: 14 Top-Rated Attractions & Places to Visit in Agra

sources.snippet: If you prefer to keep your feet on land but still want a more unique view of the Taj, then check out the Mehtab Bagh. It’s a garden complex on the north side of the Yamuna River, which has unobstructed views of the backside of the Taj Mahal. With the river in the foreground and the Taj Mahal in the distance, it offers a different perspective than you’d see on the grounds of the Taj.
sources.shortName: 13 Instagram-Worthy Spots in Agra with Examples

sources.snippet: These gardens, right opposite the Taj Mahal, are perfect spot for clicking the Taj Mahal during the day. Legend has it that Shah Jahan thought of the gardens as the perfect place for viewing the Taj Mahal and absorbing the beauty of the mausoleum. He was right because the gardens offer a great vantage point for absorbing the beauty of the Taj Mahal.
sources.shortName: 5 BEST ways of photographing the Taj Mahal, Agra

sources.snippet: Dusshera Ghat is much closer to the Taj than Mehtab Bagh, which takes a lot of time to go to, and is far away, on the other side of the Yamuna. If you only have limited time in Agra, then I recommend going here for another perspective of the Taj. Besides, it is where you can get the only running boat from (more on that below).
sources.shortName: 12 Best Taj Mahal Viewpoints in Agra, India

sources.snippet: One of the most visited tourist gardens in Agra, Mehtab Bagh, is a tranquil park which should be on your bucket list while planning a visit to Agra. Mehtab Bagh offers the most outstanding views of the grand mausoleum and is the best spot to click that perfect picture you can show off. It is the most crowded place at sunset.
sources.shortName: 21 Top Things to do in Agra in 2020 with Reviews, Photos & Price

sources.snippet: If you want a peaceful view of Taj Mahal away from crowds, move towards Mehtab Bagh which is situated near Yamuna River giving panoramic views of the monument. It was here during sunset especially as light fades out that turning golden then reflected into Yamuna River ideal for long exposure or reflections shots.
sources.shortName: Discover The Top 10 Photography Spots In Historic Agra For Stunning Shots

sources.snippet: Located in the western banks of River Yamuna and spreaded over 300 acres, Mehtab Bagh is a popular heritage tourist attraction to explore in Agra. It is said that the Mughal emperor Babur built 11 pleasure gardens and this Bagh is the last of them. You can also view the Taj Mahal from this beautiful garden.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Tourist Places to Visit in Agra | Agra Tour

sources.snippet: Mehtab Bagh in Agra stands at the North of the Taj Mahal and Agra Fort along the bank of river Yamuna. This is one of the many hidden places to visit in Agra. The garden is a char bagh which is a quadrilateral garden layout inspired by the four gardens of paradise mentioned in the Quran.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Agra, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: Situated on the banks of the river Yamuna the Mehtab Bagh is one of the last Mughal gardens. Providing the aesthetical backdrop of the Taj Mahal, a shoot at Mehtab Bagh accentuates the beauty of the pictures. The Mehtab bagh also houses the ruins of the black Taj.
sources.shortName: #15 Beautiful Prewedding Shoot Locations In Agra To Spruce Up Your Romance

Our evening at Mehtab Bagh with friends was the absolute highlight of our Agra visit—a perfectly serene and breathtaking alternative to the crowds at the Taj Mahal. Located directly across the Yamuna River, this charbagh (Mughal garden) offers the most stunning and uninterrupted panoramic view of the Taj Mahal, especially as the sun begins to set and the white marble glows in the golden light. It was the ideal spot for our group to relax, take incredible photos, and simply soak in the majestic beauty of one of the world’s wonders in a peaceful, unhurried atmosphere. The gardens themselves are well-maintained and spacious, giving us plenty of room to stroll, sit on the lawns, and enjoy the reflective ambiance away from the noise. Whether you're a photography enthusiast, a history lover, or just looking for a memorable place to unwind with friends, Mehtab Bagh delivers a magical and almost surreal experience. It’s the perfect way to end a day in Agra—calm, beautiful, and utterly unforgettable. Highly recommended for anyone wanting to see the Taj Mahal from a unique and picture-perfect perspective!

sources.snippet: A staggering sight notwithstanding its status as almost a stock image, the poignancy of the white marble architectural masterpiece led poet Rabindranath Tagore to describe the Taj as “a teardrop on the cheek of eternity.” While the rest of the city can feel a bit crowded with souvenir vendors and tour guides longing to help you preserve your memories of the Taj, the Agra Fort , a well preserved red brick structure built by Emperor Akbar, and Mughal gardens await the traveler ready to look a bit deeper. Likewise, an overnight or two will afford the chance to contemplate the Yamuna river while sampling local petha candy or savory snacks called chaat. Don't leave without also visiting the splendid Baby Taj .

sources.snippet: The Taj Mahal isn't the only UNESCO World Heritage Site in Agra–the city is also home to Agra Fort, a centuries-old red sandstone fortress that was once the imperial city for a succession of Mughal rulers. Sightseeing here is like wandering around a city within a city. The most extraordinary building at Agra Fort is Jahangir Mahal, a massive palace that blends stunning Hindu-inspired features (like overhanging enclosed balconies) with Central Asian architectural elements (such as the signature pointed arches).

The tomb is made entirely of marble and features intricate marble inlay work, delicate carvings, and beautiful lattice screens.

reviews.reviewText:
Our recent visit to the Tomb of Itmad-ud-Daula was a really good experience, a nice change from the usual super-crowded tourist spots in Agra. The place is right next to the road, so it's easy to get to. We bought our tickets from the counter, which is just to the left as you enter the main gate. It only cost us ₹25 per person.

The whole complex is so well-kept, hats off to the department taking care of it. Even when the sun was blazing, the gardens were so green and well-maintained that it felt cool and pleasant. The main monument has a red stone frame at the entrance, and inside, there's this beautiful white marble building. To go inside the marble monument, we had to remove our footwear at the foot stand on the left.

We went without a guide and saw that most people were doing the same. It was nice to just walk around, observe the tiny patterns, and later, we looked up some info on the internet to learn more. A big plus was that there were no sellers bothering us to buy things, which is a rare thing at tourist places here.

The inside of the structure is also very good. It's a great spot for taking photos, and for people who love nature, you can see the Yamuna River from the side. The cool breeze from the river really made the experience even better. They do have a washroom facility, but when we went, the staff told us there was no water.

Overall, it was a very good experience, especially compared to the other overcrowded places in Agra.

Nothing better than this. How could we not know about such beautiful monument. Amazing, marvellous, majestic. Taj Mahal is huge but this is intricate, subtle, nuanced, artistic and amazing. Must visit

A hidden gem in Agra often overshadowed by the Taj Mahal.
The intricate marble inlay work and peaceful garden make it a photographer’s delight.
Far less crowded, offering a calm and serene experience.
Perfect spot to admire Mughal craftsmanship up close.
Highly recommended for history and architecture lovers!

Often overshadowed by its more famous counterpart, the Itmad-ud-Daula's Tomb, or "Baby Taj," is an absolute must-visit in Agra. Stepping into this monument is like discovering a hidden gem. The serene gardens and the peaceful atmosphere provide a tranquil escape from the bustling city.

Our visit to the Baby Taj (Itimad-ud-Daulah) with friends was a surprisingly delightful and serene highlight of our Agra trip, offering a more intimate and peaceful experience compared to its grander counterpart. Often called the "jewel box" or a "draft of the Taj Mahal," this exquisite mausoleum captivated us with its intricate marble inlay work, delicate pietra dura designs, and beautiful gardens along the Yamuna River. Without the overwhelming crowds, we could truly appreciate the craftsmanship up close, wandering through the charbagh gardens and taking stunning photographs of the detailed mosaics and lattice screens. It felt like discovering a hidden gem—a perfect blend of history, art, and tranquility. The calm atmosphere made it ideal for a relaxed yet culturally rich outing with friends, sparking conversations about Mughal architecture and the moving love story behind its creation. For anyone touring Agra, the Baby Taj is an absolute must-see for its understated elegance and historical significance—a peaceful retreat that beautifully showcases the artistry that inspired the Taj Mahal itself.

Itimad ud Daulah is the actually a tomb of and was built by Nur Jahan, the wife of Mughal Emperor Jahangir, in memory of her father, Mirza Ghiyas Beg, who was given the title Itimad-ud-Daulah. The mausoleum is located in Agra and is also known as "Baby Taj" due to its intricate marble work and resemblance to the Taj Mahal.

This is not of much interest for most of the people but as we had some time so decided to come here, its little outside and will have usually a less crowd and it has beutiful garden also which surrounds it.

The Baby Taj is a hidden gem in Agra, often overshadowed by the Taj Mahal but equally mesmerizing in its own way. Built entirely of white marble and inlaid with delicate semi-precious stones, it’s considered the “jewel box” of Mughal architecture and a precursor to the Taj Mahal. The intricate carvings and lattice screens are incredibly detailed and worth admiring up close. Unlike the Taj, the Baby Taj is usually less crowded, offering a peaceful and intimate experience. The serene gardens and quiet atmosphere make it a perfect place to soak in history and beauty without the hustle. A must-visit spot for anyone exploring Agra.
A bit more ornate than the Taj while retaining similar characteristics. Worth seeing for sure. You have to take off your shoes or wear shoe covers though.

placeMetadata.name: Chini Ka Rauza

sources.snippet: After visiting Itimad-ud-Daulah's Tomb, head one kilometer north to see Chini ka Rauza, a funerary monument that houses the tomb of Afzal Khan Shirazi, who served as the prime minister for Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan. While not nearly as well preserved as other attractions in Agra, the Indo-Persian structure is noteworthy for being the first monument to feature chini, a distinctive decoration made from turquoise, yellow, green, and orange glazed tiles. As the name of the building suggests, each of its tiles were imported from China–an impressive feat during the 17th century, when this monument was constructed.

sources.snippet: A lesser-explored architectural gem, Chini Ka Rauza boasts intricate Persian-inspired tile work and a peaceful ambience. Chini ka Rauza is a funerary monument, containing the tomb of Afzal Khan Shirazi, a scholar and poet who was the Grand Vizier of the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan. This secluded tomb provides a romantic setting for pre-wedding shoots, pairing architectural elegance with a touch of tranquillity.

government or a corporate restores this to its original beauty.Entry is free.

*Chini Ka Rauza: A Hidden Gem of Agra*

Chini Ka Rauza is a lesser-known yet stunning monument in Agra, India, showcasing exquisite Mughal architecture. This beautiful tomb, built in the 17th century, is dedicated to Afzal Khan, a renowned poet and statesman of the Mughal era.

*Key Highlights:*

- *Unique Architecture*: Chini Ka Rauza boasts a striking blend of Persian and Indian architectural styles, with intricate tile work and calligraphy adorning its walls.
- *Tranquil Ambiance*: The monument's serene surroundings provide a peaceful retreat from Agra's bustling streets.
- *Historical Significance*: Chini Ka Rauza offers insights into the life and times of Afzal Khan and the cultural heritage of the Mughal era.
- *Less Crowded*: Compared to other Agra attractions, Chini Ka Rauza receives relatively fewer visitors, allowing for a more relaxed experience.

*Tips for Visitors:*

- *Visit During Early Morning or Late Afternoon*: The soft light enhances the beauty of the monument's tile work and architecture.
- *Explore the Surroundings*: Take a stroll around the monument to appreciate its tranquility and beauty.
- *Guided Tour*: Consider hiring a guide to gain deeper insights into the monument's history and significance.

*Overall Experience:*

Chini Ka Rauza is a hidden gem that offers a glimpse into Agra's rich cultural heritage. With its unique architecture, tranquil ambiance, and historical significance, it's a must-visit destination for anyone exploring Agra's lesser-known attractions. Don't miss this opportunity to discover the beauty and history of Chini Ka Rauza!

placeMetadata.name: Agra Fort

sources.snippet: The Agra Fort, a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in the city of Agra, is a monumental testament to the grandeur of the Mughal Empire. Built by Emperor Akbar in 1565, this sprawling red sandstone fortress stands as a symbol of power, resilience, and architectural brilliance. Its imposing double-wall fortifications, which rise over 20 meters in height, enclose a complex of exquisite buildings, including the Jahangiri Mahal, Diwan-i-Aam, Diwan-i-Khas, and Sheesh Mahal, among others.
sources.shortName: 9 Best Tourist Places To Visit In Agra In One Day

sources.snippet: Visiting Agra Fortis a complete guide to the architect of the Mughal era. The big corridors surrounded by the different section which exhibits the royal and elegant lifestyles of Mughal rulers is a full day trip in itself. Diwan-i am, Diwan -e -Khas, Sheesh Mahal, Jahangir Palace, a huge bathtub of Jahangir, The rampart of Agra fort, and many other attractions inside the massive Red stone fort is what will keep you engaged throughout the day.

reviews.reviewText:
Great Place. Only Rs.50/- ticket and worth visiting.

Take a guide if possible since no detail is written inside near the monuments

Guides will start from around Rs.2000/- charge but you may easily negotiate for Rs. 500/-

If you are a good negotiator and depending on the season, you may get it for even Rs.200/-

Agra Fort, also known as Agra's Red Fort, is a historic Mughal fort in Agra, India. Built in 1565 by Akbar as a military structure, it was later transformed into a palace by Shah Jahan. This 94-acre fort is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, featuring impressive imperial quarters, mosques, and gardens. Notable structures include the Jahangiri Mahal, Khas Mahal, and Mussaman Burj, where Shah Jahan was imprisoned by Aurangzeb. The fort showcases Mughal architecture, blending Islamic and Hindu styles. It's open daily from 6 am to 6 pm, with an entrance fee of Rs 50 for Indians and Rs 600 for foreigners

Amazing Architecture. Grandeur visited!! Only thing is.. we forgot our water bottle..  there is no drinking water facility available inside. It's only near the gate which is far off and the fort area is huge..

It was a friends short trip so we had fun visiting fort. First time visitors should get a guide although make them lower their prices. The cloaking room is free.
If you want quiet and quality time then i suggest go on week days.

Few of the parts of fort are really smelly. Although the scenes are good from fort top. It's near by taj mahal too.

Outside you can find stalls and accessories in cheap prices.

You definitely need a guide to show you around as there's limited signage but the background is fascinating. There also an optical illusion from a certain room viewing the Taj that's quite trippy. The site is pretty huge so you could spend well over an hour here. Buy your tickets online.

Agra Fort is not just a monument, it’s a walk through time. The moment I entered, I could feel the powerful energy of the Mughal Empire still alive in its massive red sandstone walls. The fort is huge and beautifully maintained, with grand gateways and a perfect mix of strong defense structures and royal elegance.

This fort is far far better than red fort situated in delhi. Jamunaji is following from just near by which can be seen from the fort clearly which makes it more beautiful. It's really clean and well maintained. All the places are open to visit for tourists unlike red fort of new delhi.
Cheap to visit and worth a visit. Not too steep to get to the top. It is a historic fort still used by the army 75% of it. Well worth a visit

The winding pathways, blooming flora and the distant silhouette of the Taj Mahal offer a picturesque setting for capturing candid moments amidst the peacefulness of nature. Taj Nature Walk, with its symmetrical charm and scenic allure, has become a popular pre-wedding shoot location in Agra, especially for couples seeking the soothing whispers of nature.

sources.snippet: Located at a distance of half a kilometer away from the Taj Mahal, the Taj Nature Walk is the green belt located on the shores of river Yamuna. The 9 km long trail is a less explored spot and is one of the unique things to do in Agra. The area is rich in a variety of flora and fauna; you can spot hyena, blue bulls, jackals, kingfishers, and various butterflies and birds.

reviews.reviewText: it is a good complex, worth the walk, or the ride! is well done overall! definitely worth a visit, it’s more for the view and to walk around. nothing really to complain about,  it a huge amount of information which is actually a nice and suitable decision for this particular occasion!

The Taj Nature Walk in Agra is a hidden gem that offers a tranquil escape from the bustling city and a unique perspective of the Taj Mahal. The lush greenery, well-maintained trails, and vibrant flora and fauna make it a refreshing experience for nature enthusiasts. The park's serene atmosphere, coupled with occasional glimpses of the Taj Mahal from different vantage points, is truly breathtaking. It's a perfect spot for a peaceful morning or evening stroll, photography, or simply unwinding amidst nature. The chirping birds and fresh air add to the charm, making it a must-visit for those who appreciate the beauty of both nature and history.

Taj nature walk cost 150 rupees for foreigners and 50 rupees for nationals. It would have been great if there was someone who wiped the benches inside the park so we could sit and enjoy the peaceful tranquility of nature. Some signage would help . Nature has lots of wild birds especially peacocks dancing around. There were three monkeys but they didn't bother us. Some areas of the walks are a bit scary especially where personal security is concerned. Although my wife and I did not feel threatened, someone alone may feel afraid. I don't think there are any security cameras. I am not trying to discourage you from visiting this place. I am just sharing my thoughts and feelings. It took us an hour to walk around. You can see the Taj Mahal at two view points. There are also tracks between bushes which later connect to the main concrete tracks. There is a canteen inside but it is closed. There is a playground for kids and a grass field for picnics. I don't know if you can take food inside but photography cameras are forbidden. Cellphone is ok.  I think the best time is early morning or late afternoon.

Taj Nature Walk is a peaceful green escape near the Taj Mahal with serene trails, lush trees, and unique views of the monument. Great for nature lovers, families, and those looking to unwind. You’ll spot birds and peacocks, enjoy clean surroundings, and find plenty of spots for photos. Highly recommended for a quiet break away from the crowds! It’s a must visit.

Have seen the changes that have occurred over the years in Taj. Nature walk from being initial place where you can just walk for some. Take it amount to now converting it into a full picnic zone. This place has truly the wyvern worth visiting

The entrance is now beautifully converted into a cafe, which definitely have the bohemian vibe. Overall, the surroundings and lovely and worth visiting.

The nature walk in Agra was something I did to occupy myself as the Taj Mahal is shut on Fridays.

It surprised me the amount of birds I seen and heard singing throughout the whole place.

It’s family friendly, has a park for children to play and a small exercise section.

You can easily spend a few hours just walking around the paths and it provides a nice green escape from the noise around the Taj Mahal

Not so well maintained nature walk.
Some trails are leading that will make you lost.
Some parts were not even cleaned up.
You can see parts of Taj Mahal, some animals such as peacocks and some common birds. April was not the best month to visit as it's so hot.

You will not believe why you are going to see on these trails…
You must follow the trail for better angles of Taj Mahal after visiting it from front….

Many of them make pilgrimages to Gurudwara Guru ka Tal, a spiritual center near Agra. This peaceful place was built in the 17th century, and modern-day tourists can see the eight towers that remain of the structure's original dozen.

The gurdwara, constructed in the 1970s, holds historical artifacts and features ornate architecture and gardens.
